lessons.title: English Practice Set (Grammar, Reading, Writing) — 33 Questions

content.text: Conventions Q1 — Choose the correct subject–verb agreement:
Either the students or the teacher ____ bringing the projector.

items: A) are
B) is

content.text: Answer: B — With either/or, the verb agrees with the nearer subject (teacher → is).
Conventions Q2 — Pronoun–antecedent agreement:
Each of the runners must show ____ bib at check‑in.

items: A) their
B) his or her

content.text: Answer: B — Indefinite singular antecedent “each” takes a singular pronoun (his or her).
Conventions Q3 — Parallelism:
The internship taught me to write reports, analyze data, and ____.

items: A) presenting findings
B) present findings

content.text: Answer: B — Keep items in a series parallel (write, analyze, present).
Conventions Q4 — Misplaced modifier:
Choose the clearer sentence.

items: A) Walking across campus, the library appeared on the left.
B) Walking across campus, I saw the library on the left.

content.text: Answer: B — The modifier should be placed next to the noun it describes (I).
Conventions Q5 — Comma usage (nonrestrictive clause):
The museum director who started last year will retire next month.

items: A) Correct as written
B) The museum director, who started last year, will retire next month.

content.text: Answer: B — Nonrestrictive information is set off with commas.
Conventions Q6 — Semicolon vs. comma splice:
Choose the correct revision.

items: A) The forecast was severe, we postponed the field trip.
B) The forecast was severe; we postponed the field trip.

content.text: Answer: B — Two independent clauses may be joined with a semicolon.
Conventions Q7 — Colon usage:
Use a colon to introduce a list: The kit contains the following ____

items: A) items, tape, gauze, and scissors
B) items: tape, gauze, and scissors

content.text: Answer: B — A complete clause before the colon introduces the list.
Conventions Q8 — Apostrophes:
Choose the correct possessive form.

items: A) the teachers lounge
B) the teachers’ lounge

content.text: Answer: B — Plural possessive for teachers is teachers’.
Conventions Q9 — Commonly confused words:
The new policy will ____ everyone’s schedule.

items: A) affect
B) effect

content.text: Answer: A — Affect is the verb meaning to influence.
Conventions Q10 — Tense consistency:
I studied the manual, take notes, and asked questions.

items: A) studied, took, and asked
B) study, take, and ask

content.text: Answer: A — Keep verbs in the same tense when listing past actions.
Conventions Q11 — Agreement with collective nouns:
The team ____ its uniforms every Friday.

items: A) wear
B) wears

content.text: Answer: B — In American English, collective nouns are usually singular (team wears).
Conventions Q12 — Hyphenation:
Choose the correct form.

items: A) a well written report
B) a well‑written report

content.text: Answer: B — Use a hyphen in a compound modifier before a noun.
Reading Q13 — Passage 1

A city neighborhood turned a vacant lot into a community garden. At first, only a few residents signed up for watering shifts and cleanup days. After the first harvest, however, the effort gained momentum. Families began trading recipes, and the local clinic offered a free class on nutrition. People who rarely spoke to one another before now swapped tomato seedlings and advice. Although the garden produced a modest amount of food, its greatest yield was social: a stronger network of neighbors who looked after the space and after one another.
Q13a — The central idea is that the garden:

items: A) failed to produce enough food to matter
B) improved community ties beyond food production
C) increased property values immediately
D) replaced all grocery shopping for participants

content.text: Answer: B — The passage emphasizes social benefits as the greatest yield.
Q13b — In context, “gained momentum” most nearly means:

items: A) shrank
B) paused
C) accelerated
D) concluded

content.text: Answer: C — Momentum refers to increasing participation and activity.
Q13c — The author’s purpose is primarily to:

items: A) argue against urban gardening
B) narrate a failed experiment
C) inform about a policy debate
D) describe community benefits of a small project

content.text: Answer: D — The paragraph describes benefits and outcomes of the garden.
Reading Q14 — Passage 2

Before the adoption of standardized time zones, towns set their clocks by the sun. The practice worked for local life but became confusing once railroads connected cities. Arrival and departure times could not be coordinated across long distances. In 1883, American railroads agreed to use four time zones to synchronize schedules. Congress later adopted the system for the country. The change did more than simplify timetables; it encouraged businesses and travelers to think on a national scale.
Q14a — The problem standardized time zones solved was:

items: A) the cost of railroad tickets
B) the lack of clocks in rural towns
C) uncoordinated schedules across distances
D) train safety regulations

content.text: Answer: C — Time zones coordinated arrival and departure times.
Q14b — The tone of the passage is best described as:

items: A) skeptical
B) informative
C) satirical
D) nostalgic

content.text: Answer: B — The passage explains historical changes in a neutral, factual way.
Q14c — According to the passage, a broader effect of time zones was that they:

items: A) reduced the number of trains in service
B) encouraged a national way of thinking
C) eliminated local traditions
D) required new kinds of clocks

content.text: Answer: B — The change encouraged national‑scale coordination.
Reading Q15 — Vocabulary in context:
In Passage 1, the word “modest” most nearly means:

items: A) extravagant
B) limited
C) accidental
D) priceless

content.text: Answer: B — Modest here means limited in amount.
Reading Q16 — Author’s technique:
Which detail best supports the claim that the garden strengthened the community?

items: A) Residents signed up for watering shifts.
B) The clinic offered a class on nutrition.
C) Families traded recipes and seedlings.
D) The harvest was modest.

content.text: Answer: C — Trading recipes and seedlings shows social connection.
Reading Q17 — Inference:
From Passage 2, one can infer that railroads:

items: A) created local noon in every town
B) were unaffected by timekeeping
C) had difficulty publishing reliable schedules before time zones
D) banned long‑distance trips

content.text: Answer: C — The passage states schedules could not be coordinated.
Reading Q18 — Structure:
Which best describes Passage 2’s organization?

items: A) cause → effect
B) comparison → contrast
C) problem → solution
D) definition → example

content.text: Answer: C — It presents a problem and the solution of standardized time.
Writing Q19 — Concision:
Choose the more concise sentence.

items: A) Due to the fact that the meeting is at 2 p.m., we will need to leave early in advance.
B) Because the meeting is at 2 p.m., we need to leave early.

content.text: Answer: B — Eliminates wordiness while keeping meaning.
Writing Q20 — Transition choice:
Which transitional word best shows contrast?

items: A) Therefore
B) However
C) Furthermore
D) For example

content.text: Answer: B — “However” signals contrast.
Writing Q21 — Evidence selection:
To support the claim that the garden improved health, which evidence is strongest?

items: A) One neighbor said the tomatoes were delicious.
B) The clinic reported a 15% increase in attendance at nutrition classes.
C) Volunteers liked working together.
D) The plot sizes were equal.

content.text: Answer: B — Quantified, relevant evidence supports the claim.
Writing Q22 — Topic sentence strength:
Choose the best topic sentence for a paragraph about the benefits of public libraries.

items: A) Libraries are buildings with books in them.
B) Public libraries provide resources and programs that expand opportunity for all ages.

content.text: Answer: B — It is focused and establishes a clear claim.
Writing Q23 — Logical order:
Which sentence should come first in a paragraph describing a process?

items: A) Finally, water the seedlings lightly after transplanting.
B) First, fill the containers with soil and label them.

content.text: Answer: B — Signals the beginning of the sequence.
Writing Q24 — Clarity (ambiguous pronoun):
Revise to remove ambiguity: “Maria told Ana that she would bring the tools.”

items: A) Maria told Ana, “I will bring the tools.”
B) Maria told Ana that Ana would bring the tools.

content.text: Answer: A — Specifies the subject clearly.
Writing Q25 — Tone and audience:
Which sentence is more appropriate for a formal report?

items: A) The pilot study was kind of successful in several ways.
B) The pilot study yielded promising results in several measures.

content.text: Answer: B — Uses precise, formal language.
Writing Q26 — Editing redundancy:
Choose the better sentence.

items: A) Each and every participant received a free gift.
B) Each participant received a gift.

content.text: Answer: B — Removes redundancy.
Writing Q27 — Combine sentences for flow:
Combine for clarity: “The device was tested. The results were accurate.”

items: A) The device was tested, and the results were accurate.
B) The device, tested, results accurate.

content.text: Answer: A — Creates a clear, grammatically complete sentence.
Conventions Q28 — Comma after introductory element:
____ finishing the survey, please submit the form.

items: A) After
B) After,

content.text: Answer: A — The comma follows the introductory phrase: After finishing the survey, …
Reading Q29 — Author’s purpose (Passage 1):

items: A) persuade the city to sell the lot
B) explain how a small project built social ties
C) warn residents about gardening rules
D) analyze the national economy

content.text: Answer: B — Purpose centers on community building.
Writing Q30 — Sentence boundaries:
Choose the sentence without a run‑on.

items: A) The streets were icy we stayed home.
B) The streets were icy, so we stayed home.

content.text: Answer: B — The coordinating conjunction and comma correctly join clauses.
Conventions Q31 — Dashes vs. commas:
Choose the option that best sets off an abrupt break.

items: A) The result—unexpected at first—was confirmed by a second trial.
B) The result, unexpected at first, was confirmed by a second trial.

content.text: Answer: A — Dashes emphasize the interruption more strongly.
Reading Q32 — Central idea (Passage 2):

items: A) Sun clocks are superior to standard time.
B) Standardized time zones supported national coordination.
C) Local noon should dictate rail schedules.
D) Clocks were banned on trains.

content.text: Answer: B — Central idea is national coordination through time zones.
Writing Q33 — Revise for clarity:
Which revision improves clarity the most?

items: A) There are many different kinds of various types of errors.
B) Several common errors occur repeatedly.

content.text: Answer: B — Removes vagueness and redundancy.
